mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Jean Augustine interview: South African Election Observer

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Recording consists of interview in which Jean Augustine discusses her 1994 trip to South Africa as an election observer.
mods:mods.mods:note: This project was supported by a research grant issued by York University Libraries.

I was an election observer in South Africa for the 19—what was it, 1994 election and um, I was in—I was sent into three different parts of South Africa to do the election monitoring. And there were different things that we were expected to do as you monitor. It’s not just an election day itself, but prior to that there were all sorts of activities that occurred. And so this really was what we would call here: posters, election posters that were up. And I found this one interesting: one party that was speaking to God and the youth, and the other was, I think these were the three parties, but what there were also showing is how you put your, how you vote, where you put your X because that was part of the situation, was educating South Africans as to how to vote. And if you saw the ballot, [it] was a huge long sheet with so many parties and so many names on there. And so this one was again the ANC party, this was one of the—I just lost the name of the party, and this was the ACDP which was the one about—the religious one; the God party. Anything you wanted to know about these?
